\begin{abstract}
The aim of this letter is to indicate a possibility of extending the current field theoretical description of Nature into the 
domain of curved field spaces, i.e.\! the phase spaces in which values of the fields ``live''. After discussing the motivation 
and general aspects of such theories we present a detailed analysis of a prototype (quantum) Curved Field Space Theory 
of a scalar field on the Minkowski background. As we show, non-vanishing curvature of the space of configurations and momenta of the 
field leads to numerous interesting predictions, including: a generalization of the uncertainty relation, 
non-localities, algebra deformations, the constrained maximal occupation number, shifting of the vacuum energy, and 
extra poles in the field propagator which are characterized by modified dispersion relations. 
\end{abstract}

\maketitle

\emph{Introduction.} Depending on its type, the field theoretical description of Nature is assigning scalars, vectors, tensors 
or spinors to the points of space. The space of all possible values of a field, i.e.\! the space of fields, is a generalization of 
the phase space for a mechanical system, with the number of degrees of freedom going to infinity. However, while 
curved phase spaces for mechanical systems have been the subject of investigations \cite{Born1938,AmelinoCamelia:2011bm}, 
the spaces of fields are typically assumed to be flat. The known exceptions are lattice field theories defined on discretized 
space-time \cite{Wilson} and non-linear sigma models, where values of a multi-component scalar field are constrained to 
lie on some Riemann manifold \cite{GellMann,Friedan}. In the latter case the constrained space is only the configuration part of the field
space.  

The aim of this letter is to consider an extension of the standard field theory to the case when the whole space of fields is 
a curved manifold. By the space of fields we mean not only the space of configurations of the field but also of the field velocities 
in the Lagrangian formulation or field momenta in the canonical formulation. In this letter we will focus on the latter situation. 

An important advantage of non-zero curvature of the field space is a possibility of restrictions on the field values. This is 
encouraging since one can expect that for physical systems only finite values of the fields are allowed. In the case of 
standard field theories arbitrary large values of a field are possible, leading to different kinds of divergences. 

Thus we conjecture the standard Field Theories (FT) to be an approximation to the more general construction that ensures 
the finiteness of values of the fields. The Curved Field Space Theory (CFST) is a proposal for imposing the latter at the 
kinematical level. We do not rule out the consideration of CFST with unrestricted values of the fields but here we would like 
to focus our attention on the constrained case. 

Before introduction of the non-linear sigma models mentioned above, some steps towards imposing the finiteness of field 
values have already been made in the mid-thirties of the XX century. In their seminal paper \cite{BornInfeld} M.~Born and 
L.~Infeld generalized the Lagrangian of electromagnetic field so that the field became constrained leading, e.g., to finite 
self-interaction energy of electron. However, in the Born-Infeld theory the field space is not curved but instead the values 
of a field are constrained dynamically by the special form of a Lagrange function. The CFST is different and more similar 
to the case of a relativistic particle, where the maximal speed of propagation is a result of the space-time geometry, 
independently on the particular form of the Lagrange or Hamilton function. For the CFST it is the geometry of a given field 
space that determines the constraints on values of the field variables. 

It is important to stress that, in spite of the similar name, CFST and Field Theories on Curved Spaces \cite{BD} are different 
things. In the latter case the field space is flat, while the background space-time manifold is curved. In CFST the field 
space is curved but the background manifold may be either flat or curved. In particular, in the example of CFST studied 
in the next section we assume that the background manifold is Minkowski space-time. 

\emph{The scalar field.} To be more specific, let us consider the CFST for the simplest type of field -- the (real) scalar field. 
In the standard case the scalar field is a function $\phi: \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}_{\phi} = \mathbb{R}$, where $\mathcal{M} 
= \Sigma \times \mathbb{R}$ is the space-time manifold. Assuming $\Sigma = \mathbb{R}^3$, the field configuration space is 
$\mathcal{C} = \mathcal{C}_{\phi}^{4 \infty} = \mathbb{R}^{4 \infty}$. In the canonical formulation the field $\phi$ is accompanied by the canonical momentum 
$\pi: \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, obeying the Poisson bracket $\left\{\phi({\bf x},t), \pi({\bf y},t)\right\} = \delta^{(3)}({\bf x - y})$. 
Then at every space-time point the pair $(\phi,\pi)$ forms the phase space $\Gamma_{({\bf x},t)} = T^*(\mathcal{C}_{\phi({\bf x},t)}) = \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}$ and the total phase space is given by $\prod_{({\bf x},t)} \Gamma_{({\bf x},t)}$. 

The idea of CFST is to generalize the phase space, so that  $\Gamma_{({\bf x},t)} \neq \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}$, 
which not necessarily has to be a cotangent bundle $T^*(\mathcal{C}_{\phi({\bf x},t)})$. The flat case of ordinary FT should be recovered 
for sufficiently small values of $\phi$ and $\pi$ (with respect to a curvature scale inbuilt in CFST).

\emph{Spherical phase space.} In order to investigate the potential consequences of non-zero curvature let 
us consider a specific example and assume $\Gamma_{\bf k}$ to be a 2-sphere: $\Gamma_{\bf k} = S^2$. 
Such a phase space is both non-trivial (e.g. it cannot be decomposed into a product of two sub-spaces) and 
compact, which guarantees the finiteness of field variables that was discussed in the Introduction. Furthermore, 
it corresponds to the phase space of a spin (angular momentum), which allows us to use intuition from the 
atomic physics.   

To define the Hamiltonian dynamics on the newly introduced phase space one first has to introduce a symplectic 
structure on it. Since $\text{dim}(\Gamma_{\bf k}) = 2$, the symplectic form $\omega$ can be naturally chosen 
as such that it is proportional to the area 2-form. By definition, this guarantees closure and non-degeneracy of 
the $\omega$ form, which is required for the definition of the Poisson bracket. 

Parametrizing the spherical phase space $\Gamma_{\bf k} = S^2$ by the standard angular variables $(\varphi,\theta)$

of the dimension of angular momentum and $\int_{S^2} \omega = 4\pi J$, as expected for the area form.

&=& \frac{i \left( 1 - \frac{2}{J} \right)}{-\omega^2 + k^2 \left( 1 - \frac{3}{J} \right) + i\epsilon} + \mathcal{O}(J^{-2}) \\
&=&\frac{i }{-\omega^2 + k^2} + \frac{i}{J} \frac{k^2 + 2\omega^2}{(-\omega^2 + k^2)^2} + \mathcal{O}(J^{-2})\,,
\label{prop}
\end{eqnarray}
where for the purpose of transparency we set $c = 1$ and $\hslash = 1$. We note that the spherical curvature 
of the field space leads to the appearance of new poles in the particle propagator. When the higher order of $1/J$ 
is included, the bigger number of additional poles can be expected. Furthermore, dispersion relations of the field 
excitations associated with the propagator's poles are supposed to become modified. However, since at any order 
the expression $\Delta E_n$ remains linear in $k$, these dispersion relations will also still be linear. What is modified 
is the speed of propagation of a given excitation. In particular, for the first pole one can deduce that the ``renormalized" 
speed of light reads $c_{\text{ren}} = 1 - \frac{3}{2} \frac{\hslash}{J} + \mathcal{O}(J^{-2})$. 

Finally, the propagator (\ref{prop}) can be used to predict the form of interaction potential between two point sources of 
the scalar field. Using the formula from \cite{Zee} we find: 
\begin{eqnarray}
V(r) &=& 4 \pi i \int \frac{d^3k}{(2\pi \hslash)^3} e^{i {\bf k \cdot r}} D_{(0,{\bf k})} Q_0 \nonumber \\
&=& -\frac{Q_0}{r} \left( 1 + \frac{\hslash}{J} + \mathcal{O}(J^{-2}) \right)\,, 
\end{eqnarray}
where $Q_0$ is the charge of a field source. It is important to note that due to the ${\bf k}$-independence 
of J (scale invariance) the functional form of the $V(r)$ potential remains the same as in the standard case. 
The only difference is a ``renormalization" of the charge $Q_{\text{ren}} = Q_0 \left(1+\frac{\hslash}{J}+\mathcal{O}(J^{-2})\right)$.

This effect, similarly to the renormalization of the speed of light discussed before, can be absorbed into 
definition of variables making the predictions possibly indistinguishable from the flat phase space results. 
Identification of measurable quantities will be crucial in the context of physical applicability of the CFST. 

\emph{Summary.} In the recent years the idea that not only the configuration space but also phase space can be curved 
attracted significant attention, especially in different approaches to quantum gravity \cite{AmelinoCamelia:2011bm,Bojowald:2011jd}. 
The purpose of this letter has been to extend this research direction into the domain of field theories, which 
for our use we call CFST. We have constructed a particular example of the CFST and showed that certain effects, which 
usually appear in the context of quantum gravity, emerge as a consequence of introducing non-zero curvature to the field phase space.

The total Hilbert space of the system is $\mathcal{H} = \bigotimes_{\bf k} \mathcal{H}_{\bf k}$, where $\mathcal{H}_{\bf k} = \text{span} \left\{|0_{\bf k} \rangle, |1_{\bf k} \rangle, \dots, |n_{\text{max},\bf k} \rangle \right\}$. The actions of the $\hat{a}^{\dagger}_{\bf k}$ and $\hat{a}_{\bf k}$ operators on the $|n_{\bf k} \rangle$ basis states are found to be:
\begin{eqnarray}
\hat{a}_{\bf k}^{\dagger} |n \rangle = \sqrt{\frac{1 - q^{n+1}}{1 - q}} |n+1 \rangle\,, \ \ 
\hat{a}_{\bf k} |n\rangle = \sqrt{\frac{1 - q^n}{1 - q}} |n-1 \rangle\,, \nonumber
\end{eqnarray}
giving the $q$-deformed expression for the occupation number operator 
$\hat{a}^{\dagger}_{\bf k} \hat{a}_{\bf k} |n_{\bf k} \rangle = \frac{1 - q^n}{1 - q} |n_{\bf k} \rangle$. 

Then (\ref{creanih}) allows us to write down the perturbative expression for the quantum counterpart of the Hamiltonian (\ref{HS2}). Symmetrizing the $\phi_{\bf k}^2 \pi_{\bf k}^2$ term (which is equivalent to the choice of an operator ordering) we obtain:
\begin{eqnarray}\label{HquatnJ-1}
\hat{H}_{\bf k} &=& -Jk\hat{\mathbb{I}} + \left(\frac{1}{2} - \frac{\hslash}{4J} \right) k\hslash\hat{\mathbb{I}} + k\hslash \left( 1 - \frac{\hslash}{J} \right) \hat{a}^{\dagger}_{\bf k} \hat{a}_{\bf k} \nonumber \\   
&+& \frac{k\hslash }{24} \frac{\hslash}{J} \left( \hat{a}_{\bf k}^4 + (\hat{a}^{\dagger}_{\bf k})^4 - 6(\hat{a}^{\dagger}_{\bf k} \hat{a}_{\bf k})^2 - 6\hat{a}^{\dagger}_{\bf k} \hat{a}_{\bf k} - 6\hat{\mathbb{I}} \right) \nonumber \\
&+& \mathcal{O}(J^{-2})\,.
\end{eqnarray} 
The Hamiltonian can be decomposed into the free and potential part and, therefore, we can apply to it the time-independent perturbation theory. In the $1$-st order 
(the $J^{-1}$ contributions) this gives us the following eigenvalues $E_n^{(1)} = -Jk + k\hslash \left( n + \frac{1}{2} \right) - k\hslash \frac{\hslash}{4J} (1 + 3n + 3n^2) + \mathcal{O}(J^{-2})$ and the corresponding eigenstates $|n^{(1)} \rangle = |n \rangle - \frac{\hslash}{96 J} \sqrt{\frac{(n+4)!}{n!}} |n+4 \rangle + \frac{\hslash}{96 J} \sqrt{\frac{n!}{(n-4)!}} |n-4 \rangle + \mathcal{O}(J^{-2})$ for a given wave number $k$. 

We note that the vacuum energy in the new ground state 
$\langle 0_{\bf k}^{(1)}| \hat{H}_{\bf k} |0_{\bf k}^{(1)} \rangle = E_0^{(1)} = -Jk + \frac{1}{2}k \hslash - \frac{1}{4} k\hslash \frac{\hslash}{J} 
+ \mathcal{O}(J^{-2})$, is reduced with respect to the standard case not only due to the factor $-Jk$ but also as the result of the contribution proportional to $J^{-1}$. Analysis of consequences of this effect in the context of the vacuum energy density and, presumably, cosmological 
constant problem is yet to be done. 

Another interesting observation is that while in the standard free  Quantum FT the field operator acting on the vacuum state is creating a single quantum $\hat{\phi}_{\bf k}(0) |0_{\bf k} \rangle = \sqrt{\frac{\hslash}{2k}} |1_{\bf k} \rangle$ with energy $E_1$, in the CFST the creation of a superposition of quanta can be naturally expected.
